title: [EPIC] Zeebe multi-tenancy support
bodyText:
Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.
Enable Zeebe to support the concept of multiple tenants. Tenant data is clearly separated per tenant while reusing a single Zeebe cluster.
Task breakdown
The goal of the first phase is to provide core multi-tenancy concepts/mechanisms in the Zeebe Broker and Gateway. These concepts will later be used as building blocks to support multi-tenancy in Zeebe.

The goal of phase 2 is to provide multi-tenancy support for core Zeebe concepts like process instances and jobs. The intention is to provide multi-tenancy support for these concepts early in the implementation so that other Camunda Platform 8 components are unblocked, and can start implementing multi-tenancy on their side as well.
Each task of phase 2 covers the vertical implementation (engine, gateway, client, data migration, documentation) for a Zeebe concept. The vertical implementation of the deployments functionality can serve as an example.

Closing this issue as the multi-tenancy epic is completed in Zeebe.

title: [EPIC] Dynamic Scaling of Zeebe Cluster - Phase 1: Number of brokers
bodyText:
Introduction
Goal: I can add or remove brokers to an existing Zeebe clusters while keeping the partitions count same.
When a user provisioned the cluster for a specific workload and later the workload is increased, the cluster can be scaled by adding more brokers and moving some of the partitions to the new brokers. This gives more resources per partition which will then be able to handle the workload. Scaling this way is limited because it depends on how many partitions were initially provisioned. However, this is the first step towards dynamic scaling Zeebe to handle increased workloads.

nodes.bodyText: Regarding "Automatic configuration changes", maybe this would be a good opportunity to build a better version of the rebalancing API. For example starting leadership transfer to rebalance when the cluster is healthy but unbalanced.

Here are some of the followups that came up in PR reviews or discussions. We should do them with in the scope of this epic. I'm just noting this here so that we don't forget. Will create issues for these later.

 Retry operations in TopologyChangeApplier or ClusterTopologyManager. Operations like partition join/leave can fail due to temporary issues like timeout, unavailability of leader. This should be retried.
 Add revapi to check backward compatibility issues with protobuf definitions in topology module
 Allow configuring cluster topology gossipper. Currently the configs such as sync interval, timeout etc.. are hard coded.
 Single member cannot leave a partition
 Engine factory should read partition count from ClusterTopology. Eventhough we don't allow change partition count yet, ClusterTopology is the source of truth. It should be possible to start a broker with wrong configuration, but it find the correct one from the coordinator.
 Add checksum in persisted cluster topology to detect corruption
 Partition join request to non existing partition should be rejected

Additional improvements

Should we specify which node is coordinator via Broker configs?
Should we allow changing coordinator dynamically?

One thing I've just noticed and that we should guard against:
One a single broker, single partition cluster, a PartitionJoinRequest for partition 2 (doesn't exist) results in the following:

the change is accepted
applying the change fails because there's no other member apart from 0 who can assist in joining
after a restart, applying the change fails because partition 2 already exists

One thing I've just noticed and that we should guard against: One a single broker, single partition cluster, a PartitionJoinRequest for partition 2 (doesn't exist) results in the following:

the change is accepted
applying the change fails because there's no other member apart from 0 who can assist in joining
after a restart, applying the change fails because partition 2 already exists


Added it to the list of pending tasks in #13642 (comment)
Updated the epic to reflect, we wouldn't be addressing the tasks in Extended for this scope.

Can we find a way where this feature can be enabled through rolling updates? This is relevant for customers enabling the experimental feature flag by hand and rolling it out as statefulset update, but also when we decide to enable it by default.
Currently, non-coordinator nodes restart first and are then stuck in the GossipInitializer until the coordinator can start.
That's a good point. I don't have an idea how to handle that now. Let's discuss.

Following issues will be addressed later as they are not critical for the completion of this epic.

#15793
#15679

Closing this Epic as completed. 🎉
What is not done as part of this Epic:

No automatic scaling based on heuristics like load
No automatic scaling when a new node is detected in the cluster. You have to explicitly trigger scaling via the rest api.

Some limitations/potential improvements:

Broker 0 is the designated code to coordinate any topology changes. When Broker 0 is not available, no other broker can take over the responsibility. This means that any scaling operation can be done when Broker 0 is healthy. Potential improvement - allow overriding this via config. Further improvement, brokers can elect a coordinator themselves based on availability.
Cancelling a stuck scaling operation is tricky and dangerous.

nodes.title: Start raft partitions based on the configuration provided by a configuration manager
Store and manage configuration via gossip
Broker uses configuration from ClusterTopologyManager
Raft members can join and leave an existing cluster
Dynamically start and stop partitions
A new broker can be added to cluster topology
A broker can be removed from the ClusterTopology
Partition distribution can be changed dynamically
Expose API to make cluster topology changes
Partition priority can be changed dynamically
QA tests for partition leave and join
QA test for broker scaling endpoint
Verify coordinator unavailability does not impact restart of a broker
Verify error responses for cluster endpoint
Chaos tests for scaling brokers
Verify partition can take snapshot and compact after scaling
Run internal 'realistic' tests on Broker Scaling
Retry topology change operations when failed.
Add a dry-run flag for scale request
Add an endpoint to cancel a stuck topology change
Failed or cancelled topology change operations block further operations
Topology received via gossip can bypass merge with locally persisted topology
Add checksum in persisted cluster topology to detect corruption
NullPointerException when join is retried after a restart
Remove partition data after leaving replication group
Add both last and pending change to get topology response
After cancellation, a completed change operation should not overwrite updated topology
Allow configuring timeouts in cluster topology gossipper
Single member cannot leave a partition
Add backward compatibility check for protobuf definitions in topology module
Earlier join and leave responses to reduce risk of unavailability
Add metrics for ongoing scaling operations

title: [EPIC] Dynamic Scaling of Zeebe Cluster - Phase 1: Number of brokers
bodyText:
Introduction
Goal: I can add or remove brokers to an existing Zeebe clusters while keeping the partitions count same.
When a user provisioned the cluster for a specific workload and later the workload is increased, the cluster can be scaled by adding more brokers and moving some of the partitions to the new brokers. This gives more resources per partition which will then be able to handle the workload. Scaling this way is limited because it depends on how many partitions were initially provisioned. However, this is the first step towards dynamic scaling Zeebe to handle increased workloads.

nodes.bodyText: Regarding "Automatic configuration changes", maybe this would be a good opportunity to build a better version of the rebalancing API. For example starting leadership transfer to rebalance when the cluster is healthy but unbalanced.

Here are some of the followups that came up in PR reviews or discussions. We should do them with in the scope of this epic. I'm just noting this here so that we don't forget. Will create issues for these later.

 Retry operations in TopologyChangeApplier or ClusterTopologyManager. Operations like partition join/leave can fail due to temporary issues like timeout, unavailability of leader. This should be retried.
 Add revapi to check backward compatibility issues with protobuf definitions in topology module
 Allow configuring cluster topology gossipper. Currently the configs such as sync interval, timeout etc.. are hard coded.
 Single member cannot leave a partition
 Engine factory should read partition count from ClusterTopology. Eventhough we don't allow change partition count yet, ClusterTopology is the source of truth. It should be possible to start a broker with wrong configuration, but it find the correct one from the coordinator.
 Add checksum in persisted cluster topology to detect corruption
 Partition join request to non existing partition should be rejected

Additional improvements

Should we specify which node is coordinator via Broker configs?
Should we allow changing coordinator dynamically?

One thing I've just noticed and that we should guard against:
One a single broker, single partition cluster, a PartitionJoinRequest for partition 2 (doesn't exist) results in the following:

the change is accepted
applying the change fails because there's no other member apart from 0 who can assist in joining
after a restart, applying the change fails because partition 2 already exists

One thing I've just noticed and that we should guard against: One a single broker, single partition cluster, a PartitionJoinRequest for partition 2 (doesn't exist) results in the following:

the change is accepted
applying the change fails because there's no other member apart from 0 who can assist in joining
after a restart, applying the change fails because partition 2 already exists


Added it to the list of pending tasks in #13642 (comment)
Updated the epic to reflect, we wouldn't be addressing the tasks in Extended for this scope.

Can we find a way where this feature can be enabled through rolling updates? This is relevant for customers enabling the experimental feature flag by hand and rolling it out as statefulset update, but also when we decide to enable it by default.
Currently, non-coordinator nodes restart first and are then stuck in the GossipInitializer until the coordinator can start.
That's a good point. I don't have an idea how to handle that now. Let's discuss.

Following issues will be addressed later as they are not critical for the completion of this epic.

#15793
#15679

Closing this Epic as completed. 🎉
What is not done as part of this Epic:

No automatic scaling based on heuristics like load
No automatic scaling when a new node is detected in the cluster. You have to explicitly trigger scaling via the rest api.

Some limitations/potential improvements:

Broker 0 is the designated code to coordinate any topology changes. When Broker 0 is not available, no other broker can take over the responsibility. This means that any scaling operation can be done when Broker 0 is healthy. Potential improvement - allow overriding this via config. Further improvement, brokers can elect a coordinator themselves based on availability.
Cancelling a stuck scaling operation is tricky and dangerous.

nodes.title: Start raft partitions based on the configuration provided by a configuration manager
Store and manage configuration via gossip
Broker uses configuration from ClusterTopologyManager
Raft members can join and leave an existing cluster
Dynamically start and stop partitions
A new broker can be added to cluster topology
A broker can be removed from the ClusterTopology
Partition distribution can be changed dynamically
Expose API to make cluster topology changes
Partition priority can be changed dynamically
QA tests for partition leave and join
QA test for broker scaling endpoint
Verify coordinator unavailability does not impact restart of a broker
Verify error responses for cluster endpoint
Chaos tests for scaling brokers
Verify partition can take snapshot and compact after scaling
Run internal 'realistic' tests on Broker Scaling
Retry topology change operations when failed.
Add a dry-run flag for scale request
Add an endpoint to cancel a stuck topology change
Failed or cancelled topology change operations block further operations
Topology received via gossip can bypass merge with locally persisted topology
Add checksum in persisted cluster topology to detect corruption
NullPointerException when join is retried after a restart
Remove partition data after leaving replication group
Add both last and pending change to get topology response
After cancellation, a completed change operation should not overwrite updated topology
Allow configuring timeouts in cluster topology gossipper
Single member cannot leave a partition
Add backward compatibility check for protobuf definitions in topology module
Earlier join and leave responses to reduce risk of unavailability
Add metrics for ongoing scaling operations

title: [EPIC] Dynamic Scaling of Zeebe Cluster - Phase 1: Number of brokers
bodyText:
Introduction
Goal: I can add or remove brokers to an existing Zeebe clusters while keeping the partitions count same.
When a user provisioned the cluster for a specific workload and later the workload is increased, the cluster can be scaled by adding more brokers and moving some of the partitions to the new brokers. This gives more resources per partition which will then be able to handle the workload. Scaling this way is limited because it depends on how many partitions were initially provisioned. However, this is the first step towards dynamic scaling Zeebe to handle increased workloads.
Task Breakdown

nodes.bodyText: Regarding "Automatic configuration changes", maybe this would be a good opportunity to build a better version of the rebalancing API. For example starting leadership transfer to rebalance when the cluster is healthy but unbalanced.

Here are some of the followups that came up in PR reviews or discussions. We should do them with in the scope of this epic. I'm just noting this here so that we don't forget. Will create issues for these later.

 Retry operations in TopologyChangeApplier or ClusterTopologyManager. Operations like partition join/leave can fail due to temporary issues like timeout, unavailability of leader. This should be retried.
 Add revapi to check backward compatibility issues with protobuf definitions in topology module
 Allow configuring cluster topology gossipper. Currently the configs such as sync interval, timeout etc.. are hard coded.
 Single member cannot leave a partition
 Engine factory should read partition count from ClusterTopology. Eventhough we don't allow change partition count yet, ClusterTopology is the source of truth. It should be possible to start a broker with wrong configuration, but it find the correct one from the coordinator.
 Add checksum in persisted cluster topology to detect corruption
 Partition join request to non existing partition should be rejected

Additional improvements

Should we specify which node is coordinator via Broker configs?
Should we allow changing coordinator dynamically?

One thing I've just noticed and that we should guard against:
One a single broker, single partition cluster, a PartitionJoinRequest for partition 2 (doesn't exist) results in the following:

the change is accepted
applying the change fails because there's no other member apart from 0 who can assist in joining
after a restart, applying the change fails because partition 2 already exists

One thing I've just noticed and that we should guard against: One a single broker, single partition cluster, a PartitionJoinRequest for partition 2 (doesn't exist) results in the following:

the change is accepted
applying the change fails because there's no other member apart from 0 who can assist in joining
after a restart, applying the change fails because partition 2 already exists


Added it to the list of pending tasks in #13642 (comment)
Updated the epic to reflect, we wouldn't be addressing the tasks in Extended for this scope.

Can we find a way where this feature can be enabled through rolling updates? This is relevant for customers enabling the experimental feature flag by hand and rolling it out as statefulset update, but also when we decide to enable it by default.
Currently, non-coordinator nodes restart first and are then stuck in the GossipInitializer until the coordinator can start.
That's a good point. I don't have an idea how to handle that now. Let's discuss.

Following issues will be addressed later as they are not critical for the completion of this epic.

#15793
#15679

Closing this Epic as completed. 🎉
What is not done as part of this Epic:

No automatic scaling based on heuristics like load
No automatic scaling when a new node is detected in the cluster. You have to explicitly trigger scaling via the rest api.

Some limitations/potential improvements:

Broker 0 is the designated code to coordinate any topology changes. When Broker 0 is not available, no other broker can take over the responsibility. This means that any scaling operation can be done when Broker 0 is healthy. Potential improvement - allow overriding this via config. Further improvement, brokers can elect a coordinator themselves based on availability.
Cancelling a stuck scaling operation is tricky and dangerous.

nodes.title: Start raft partitions based on the configuration provided by a configuration manager
Store and manage configuration via gossip
Broker uses configuration from ClusterTopologyManager
Raft members can join and leave an existing cluster
Dynamically start and stop partitions
A new broker can be added to cluster topology
A broker can be removed from the ClusterTopology
Partition distribution can be changed dynamically
Expose API to make cluster topology changes
Partition priority can be changed dynamically
QA tests for partition leave and join
QA test for broker scaling endpoint
Verify coordinator unavailability does not impact restart of a broker
Verify error responses for cluster endpoint
Chaos tests for scaling brokers
Verify partition can take snapshot and compact after scaling
Run internal 'realistic' tests on Broker Scaling
Retry topology change operations when failed.
Add a dry-run flag for scale request
Add an endpoint to cancel a stuck topology change
Failed or cancelled topology change operations block further operations
Topology received via gossip can bypass merge with locally persisted topology
Add checksum in persisted cluster topology to detect corruption
NullPointerException when join is retried after a restart
Remove partition data after leaving replication group
Add both last and pending change to get topology response
After cancellation, a completed change operation should not overwrite updated topology
Allow configuring timeouts in cluster topology gossipper
Single member cannot leave a partition
Add backward compatibility check for protobuf definitions in topology module
Earlier join and leave responses to reduce risk of unavailability
Add metrics for ongoing scaling operations

title: Inconsistent/unnecessary escaping of characters in inputs
bodyText:
Describe the bug
As a user I want to pass special chars in strings (FEEL ref) in a way that I can consume them in a job worker.
I've defined the following input mappings:



name
value




dynamic_input
= "Hello\n\nYOU!"


static_input
Hello\n\nYOU!


static_input_explicit_newlines
HELLO<newline><newline>YOU!



Executing my process I receive the following input variable values in operate (but also in my process worker):



name
value




dynamic_input
"Hello\\n\\nYOU!"


static_input
"Hello\\\\n\\\\nYOU!"


static_input_explicit_newlines
"Hello\\n\\nYOU!"



As you can see inputs are escaped differently depending on whether I use \n encoded newlines or actual newline characters. Escaping happening in the first place is fine I believe as this is a JSON string and \\n is the standard way to encode newlines there.
To Reproduce

Deploy + run test process
See double escaping happening in string inputs

Expected behavior
We do the unescaping magic ourselves so that in user land no one needs to worry:

I define an input mapping foo = "a\nb"
In my job worker I see foo = "a\nb"

As a more user un-friendly alternative we could consider: String inputs are escaped like expression inputs (no double escaping), we clearly document how escaped strings shall be worked with (and how un-escaping has to be done in user land). This is closer to the existing behavior.
Log/Stacktrace
none.
Environment:

OS: Linux
Zeebe Version: 8.0.2
Configuration: nothing special

Support:
SUPPORT-15887
SUPPORT-17621

nodes.bodyText:
To add to this I see zeebe escaping unicode characters (i.e. 🤩) despite JSON having full unicode support.
Hello\n\nYOU! 🤩

turns into
"Hello\\n\\nYOU! \uD83E\uDD29"


"Hello\\n\\nYOU! 🤩" is a valid JSON string.
Is there a chance this can be fixed at some point? Or do we regard this as a nasty-bug-turned-public-api?
@felix-mueller this is something which mostly effects connectors but it is very unexpected behavior. We would like to understand if you have any input on priority for this.

It should be fixed at some point. Since we still need to root-cause and better understand the issue it is probably not S. We won't priotize it for the next few iterations (first we need to finish instance modification, DMN evaluation and delete definitions).
Thanks Felix, I put the priority on "Later" for now

I don't know whether I'm hitting the same issue. I'm using the Go client to ingest JSON formatted data into Zeebe. Jobs are failing due to escaped double quotes. If I set vars manually via simple-monitor everything works as expected.
Hi team, is there any ETA to fix this? It is affecting currently 3 connectors.

@igpetrov currently we have planned to look into it after instance modification, DMN evaluation and Delete Definitions. these topics are scheduled to be included in our April minor release, so if we don't change priorities we probably will look at it in a few months.
from connectors perspective can we live with this for a few months?
Hi @felix-mueller, appreciate your update. Absolutely. Just wanted to understand the ETA. Thank you!

For reference, in Connectors, we currently do the following to work around this with data we receive as variables after Zeebe has processed the user input:
StringEscapeUtils.unescapeJson(jsonStringVariable)

This uses StringEscapeUtils from org.apache.commons:commons-text.
@felix-mueller The longer we keep such behavior in the core, the harder it will be for people to unbuild their hacks (trying to work with zeebe data). My 2️⃣ 🪙.
A similar issue is reported by a customer through SUPPORT-15887.
I've updated the issue with a clear expected behavior, reflecting https://jira.camunda.com/browse/SUPPORT-15887, but also #9859 (comment) have reported.
Discussed in the planning meeting on 2023-02-17. Right now we don't have capacity to work on this, and deprioritize it as the customer has a workaround available.

When we work on this, we need to make sure not to break user space when backporting it to patches. We can do this by adding a configuration setting that allows switching between the current (broken) and new (fixed) behaviors. The default should stay the same in patch releases, but in a minor release we can change the default. This should be clearly communicated in the release notes (and blog) so users understand the change.
This issue was mentioned again in SUPPORT-17621 and blocking connectors team's here

When we resolve this issue, please verify whether the fix also resolves:

#13551
Also came across this, the StringEscapeUtils.unescapeJson workaround works for now but would be nice to have this fixed soon :)

I run into this issue when using the GH outbound connector and create a new issue with a multi line description field.  As this is a quite common use case I'm wondering when we are planning to provide a fix. @felix-mueller is this still scheduled for the 8.5 release in April 2024?
Would camunda/product-hub#1040 help here or is it just a quick fix on string behavior?

@nicpuppa started to work on this issue by fixing the escaping in the FEEL engine here. We plan to deliver a fix in one of the next patch releases. 🚀
@christian-konrad the FEEL templating is a bigger topic. Let's fix the issue with the escaping first. 👍
Perfect @saig0 ! Thanks

Hi @abbasadel ,
according to the previous assessment this should have been fixed with this version bump. Can you verify from Zeebe perspective please and update this issue? Thanks

We need to clarify whether this change is breaking, especially in regards to present workaround in other components such as camunda/connector-slack#48 &
camunda/connector-google-drive#20
While for the REST connector no workaround seems to be in place and there a patch by zeebe would resolve the issue.
If it's breaking we may prefer to only release it in the next minor or at least coordinate with the affected components to remove the workaround applied for a patch. But then we have the risk that we have a dependency between patch levels of connectors and zeebe.
@abbasadel will sync with @saig0 on this tomorrow and ping back.

Hi everyone, this is Zeebe's assessment:

The recent bug fix on the FEEL engine is not backward compatible from Zeebe's point of view. However, we believe, based on @saig0’s feedback and our tests, the impact on our users is low since the recommended workaround we provided was to use unescapeJson API from Apache Commons which handles breaking change.
As the previous behavior was wrong, mentioning the new behavior change in the release notes and as an announcement would be needed
This FEEL fix should resolve bug, to be validated by Connectors/Operate teams.
The support team should also be aware of this FEEL behavior change once release

Hi everyone, this is Zeebe's assessment:

The recent bug fix on the FEEL engine is not backward compatible from Zeebe's point of view. However, we believe, based on @saig0’s feedback and our tests, the impact on our users is low since the recommended workaround we provided was to use unescapeJson API from Apache Commons which handles breaking change.
As the previous behavior was wrong, mentioning the new behavior change in the release notes and as an announcement would be needed
This FEEL fix should resolve bug, to be validated by Connectors/Operate teams.
The support team should also be aware of this FEEL behavior change once release


Thanks @abbasadel . Will you and the ZPA team please ensure that all these things happen? If so, can we please track this via a breakdown and DRI assignments? Why is the issue not in in progress and has no assignee?
@MaxTru, we will take care of this issue

Hi everyone, as follow up I created 3 separate issues to reduce the scope and make easier to follow the progress:

Verify correct behaviour of input mappings after bump to FEEL 1.17.3 -> this is a testing purpose issue, to verify that the new FEEL version has the correct behaviour
Special characters in static inputs should not be escaped -> as mentioned also by @saig0 in this comment, characters in static input are still escaped. Static input are handled directly by Zeebe
Verify unicode characters are not escaped in input mappings -> after resolving the feel issue related to unicode, on Zeebe we should verify that the behaviour is as expected (unicode characters should not be escaped)

In accordance with @abbasadel and @saig0 I will close this issue This issue is still open only for tracking purpose, I mistakenly closed the issue

Thanks, @nicpuppa, for the updates.
I added the sub-issues into the main issue description for clarity and tracking purpose

Hi everyone,

The dynamic_input unnecessary escaping bug is currently resolved in Zeebe 8.3.4 release
The bug fix is #15445 resolves the connectors team bug. Thanks @saig0 and @nicpuppa
The corrected behavior change is highlighted in the release notes. Thanks @saig0 for the wording.
The support team is informed about the corrected behavior change
Next action: Update input mappings docs as suggested by @akeller

@abbasadel will this be included with the alpha release next week? Since this is a Zeebe task, I'm not sure what the expectation is. When you open your docs PR, please follow our PR template so we can review ASAP if you want it reviewed, merged, and published on Tuesday.
Thanks @akeller. The docs PR is already merged

title: Inconsistent/unnecessary escaping of characters in inputs
bodyText:
Describe the bug
As a user I want to pass special chars in strings (FEEL ref) in a way that I can consume them in a job worker.
I've defined the following input mappings:



name
value




dynamic_input
= "Hello\n\nYOU!"


static_input
Hello\n\nYOU!


static_input_explicit_newlines
HELLO<newline><newline>YOU!



Executing my process I receive the following input variable values in operate (but also in my process worker):



name
value




dynamic_input
"Hello\\n\\nYOU!"


static_input
"Hello\\\\n\\\\nYOU!"


static_input_explicit_newlines
"Hello\\n\\nYOU!"



As you can see inputs are escaped differently depending on whether I use \n encoded newlines or actual newline characters. Escaping happening in the first place is fine I believe as this is a JSON string and \\n is the standard way to encode newlines there.
To Reproduce

Deploy + run test process
See double escaping happening in string inputs

Expected behavior
We do the unescaping magic ourselves so that in user land no one needs to worry:

I define an input mapping foo = "a\nb"
In my job worker I see foo = "a\nb"

As a more user un-friendly alternative we could consider: String inputs are escaped like expression inputs (no double escaping), we clearly document how escaped strings shall be worked with (and how un-escaping has to be done in user land). This is closer to the existing behavior.
Log/Stacktrace
none.
Environment:

OS: Linux
Zeebe Version: 8.0.2
Configuration: nothing special

Support:
SUPPORT-15887
SUPPORT-17621

title: [EPIC] Dynamic Scaling of Zeebe Cluster - Phase 1: Number of brokers
bodyText:
Introduction
Goal: I can add or remove brokers to an existing Zeebe clusters while keeping the partitions count same.
When a user provisioned the cluster for a specific workload and later the workload is increased, the cluster can be scaled by adding more brokers and moving some of the partitions to the new brokers. This gives more resources per partition which will then be able to handle the workload. Scaling this way is limited because it depends on how many partitions were initially provisioned. However, this is the first step towards dynamic scaling Zeebe to handle increased workloads.

nodes.bodyText: Regarding "Automatic configuration changes", maybe this would be a good opportunity to build a better version of the rebalancing API. For example starting leadership transfer to rebalance when the cluster is healthy but unbalanced.

Here are some of the followups that came up in PR reviews or discussions. We should do them with in the scope of this epic. I'm just noting this here so that we don't forget. Will create issues for these later.

 Retry operations in TopologyChangeApplier or ClusterTopologyManager. Operations like partition join/leave can fail due to temporary issues like timeout, unavailability of leader. This should be retried.
 Add revapi to check backward compatibility issues with protobuf definitions in topology module
 Allow configuring cluster topology gossipper. Currently the configs such as sync interval, timeout etc.. are hard coded.
 Single member cannot leave a partition
 Engine factory should read partition count from ClusterTopology. Eventhough we don't allow change partition count yet, ClusterTopology is the source of truth. It should be possible to start a broker with wrong configuration, but it find the correct one from the coordinator.
 Add checksum in persisted cluster topology to detect corruption
 Partition join request to non existing partition should be rejected

Additional improvements

Should we specify which node is coordinator via Broker configs?
Should we allow changing coordinator dynamically?

One thing I've just noticed and that we should guard against:
One a single broker, single partition cluster, a PartitionJoinRequest for partition 2 (doesn't exist) results in the following:

the change is accepted
applying the change fails because there's no other member apart from 0 who can assist in joining
after a restart, applying the change fails because partition 2 already exists

One thing I've just noticed and that we should guard against: One a single broker, single partition cluster, a PartitionJoinRequest for partition 2 (doesn't exist) results in the following:

the change is accepted
applying the change fails because there's no other member apart from 0 who can assist in joining
after a restart, applying the change fails because partition 2 already exists


Added it to the list of pending tasks in #13642 (comment)
Updated the epic to reflect, we wouldn't be addressing the tasks in Extended for this scope.

Can we find a way where this feature can be enabled through rolling updates? This is relevant for customers enabling the experimental feature flag by hand and rolling it out as statefulset update, but also when we decide to enable it by default.
Currently, non-coordinator nodes restart first and are then stuck in the GossipInitializer until the coordinator can start.
That's a good point. I don't have an idea how to handle that now. Let's discuss.

Following issues will be addressed later as they are not critical for the completion of this epic.

#15793
#15679

Closing this Epic as completed. 🎉
What is not done as part of this Epic:

No automatic scaling based on heuristics like load
No automatic scaling when a new node is detected in the cluster. You have to explicitly trigger scaling via the rest api.

Some limitations/potential improvements:

Broker 0 is the designated code to coordinate any topology changes. When Broker 0 is not available, no other broker can take over the responsibility. This means that any scaling operation can be done when Broker 0 is healthy. Potential improvement - allow overriding this via config. Further improvement, brokers can elect a coordinator themselves based on availability.
Cancelling a stuck scaling operation is tricky and dangerous.

nodes.title: Start raft partitions based on the configuration provided by a configuration manager
Store and manage configuration via gossip
Broker uses configuration from ClusterTopologyManager
Raft members can join and leave an existing cluster
Dynamically start and stop partitions
A new broker can be added to cluster topology
A broker can be removed from the ClusterTopology
Partition distribution can be changed dynamically
Expose API to make cluster topology changes
Partition priority can be changed dynamically
QA tests for partition leave and join
QA test for broker scaling endpoint
Verify coordinator unavailability does not impact restart of a broker
Verify error responses for cluster endpoint
Chaos tests for scaling brokers
Verify partition can take snapshot and compact after scaling
Run internal 'realistic' tests on Broker Scaling
Retry topology change operations when failed.
Add a dry-run flag for scale request
Add an endpoint to cancel a stuck topology change
Failed or cancelled topology change operations block further operations
Topology received via gossip can bypass merge with locally persisted topology
Add checksum in persisted cluster topology to detect corruption
NullPointerException when join is retried after a restart
Remove partition data after leaving replication group
Add both last and pending change to get topology response
After cancellation, a completed change operation should not overwrite updated topology
Allow configuring timeouts in cluster topology gossipper
Single member cannot leave a partition
Add backward compatibility check for protobuf definitions in topology module
Earlier join and leave responses to reduce risk of unavailability
Add metrics for ongoing scaling operations

title: [EPIC] Basic Process Instance Migration
bodyText:
Introduction

Keep your running instances up-to-date with the latest process improvements (public roadmap issue).
Process Instance Migration is a feature that is available in Camunda 7 that allows process instances to be 'migrated' to another process model. Typically, this is useful when the process definition needs to be changed due to bugs or new requirements. This epic aims to add basic process instance migration functionality for relatively simple process definitions.
Efforts on this feature start from lessons learned from the following issues, where we identified several potential iterations. However, that concept was overthrown after spiking another approach where we don't cancel the process instance and create a new instance using the target process definition, but rather adjust the existing process instance in such a way that the keys (process instance key, job keys, etc) remain the same:

#11099
#14960

This means that Process Instance Migration will allow users to migrate an existing process instance to a new process definition, but this will come with certain restrictions. For example, the type of an activity cannot be changed when mapping it in the migration plan.
Users can use Cancel Process Instance in combination with Create and Start at a User-Defined Element to overcome the limitations of Process Instance Migration, at the cost of losing the original process instance and a re-creation of the associated keys.
Requirements and limitations
Process instances can only be migrated under the following requirements and limitations. The reasoning for each statement can be found by expanding the details.
Process instance migration can only migrate active process instances, i.e. existing process instances that have not yet been completed, terminated, or banned

Terminated and completed process instances are removed from Zeebe, so Zeebe has no knowledge about them anymore.
Banned process instances still exist in Zeebe. However, they are isolated from active instances so that they don't cause further damage. Banned instances cannot be recovered, but allow investigation by Zeebe developers to troubleshoot severe bugs.

 
All active elements require a mapping (including active Sub Processes)

We require all active elements in a process instance to have an explicit mapping in the migration plan. This is also a requirement for active Sub Processes.
When a Sub Process is added nesting a mapped active element, the engine assumes that the user wants to have a new element instance of that Sub Process. Likewise, when a Sub Process nesting a mapped active element is removed, the engine could assume that the user wants to remove the element instance of that Sub Process. However, when a Sub Process nesting a mapped active element remains, the user likely wants to reuse the element instance of the Sub Process. For example, if variables exist at this Sub Process, they wouldn't expect to lose them.
Now consider the case where a Sub Process nesting a mapped active element remains, but its element ID is changed. Should the engine consider this a different Sub Process from the active one, or does the user mean that this is the same Sub Process? There is no way for the engine to decide this for the user.
To highlight this, let's add one additional Sub Process to the target process nesting the Sub Process with the adjusted ID. In the example, we map Task A to A, what should happen to the instance of Sub Process Sub 1 and any variables existing on it?


If we recreate the Sub Process

The variables are lost
Or the engine has to add logic to copy the variables automatically and choose between Sub 2 and Sub 3


If we adjust the Sub Process as Migrated

The engine has to choose between Sub 2 and Sub 3 as migration target and create an instance of the other



In both scenarios, the engine has to make a choice that it can't really make.
The alternative is to require users to provide a mapping for all active elements, including active Sub Processes. The engine can still assume to create new element instances for Sub Processes added to the hierarchy in the target process. When an active Sub Process is removed from the hierarchy, the user can provide an explicit mapping to:

a target Sub Process -> to migrate and keep the element instance
no element "" (empty string) -> to terminate the element instance

This has several advantages:

The expected outcome of the migration plan is clear because the mappings are explicit
If the ID of a Sub Process is changed in a target process and the user forgets to map the Sub Process, it will otherwise lead to the loss of local variables existing at the Sub Process, or the engine has to make a choice for the user about copying the variables. This mistake could be easily made, so we should protect the user.


 
Mapping instructions cannot change the element type

If we would allow changing the element type, then type-specific expressions and entities may have to be created and/or removed depending on the mapping. This quickly leads to difficult situations.
For example, when mapping a service task to a user task, we'd have to remove the job, evaluate user-specific expressions (e.g. assignee), and create a new job with the new information, or adjust the existing job with the new info. If the type changes further from task to gateway, this also leads to more required changes. For Zeebe, it's best to keep this complexity under control and restrict how elements can be migrated.
Zeebe provides a way to move elements between elements of different types with the Process Instance Modification functionality. Users can modify and migrate a process instance in a two or three-step procedure:

Migrate a process instance, keeping the active element unchanged and introducing a new element with a different type
Modify the process instance, moving the active element to the newly introduced element
Migrate the process instance, removing the no longer needed element from the process


 
The target process definition must exist in Zeebe (deployed and not deleted)

This requirement should not raise any eyebrows. Zeebe must know what the target process looks like in order to migrate a process instance to it.

 
A mapping instruction's `sourceElementId` must refer to an element existing in the source process

If the mapping refers to a non-existing element id, then the user might have made a mistake in their mapping instructions. Instead of just accepting this, we prefer to point out the mistake. As process instance migration is a power tool, it's possible to damage a process instance. Therefore, we feel it's best to support the user wherever possible.

 
A mapping instruction's `targetElementId` must refer to an element existing in the target process (or refer to no element, i.e. `""` empty string)

Exactly similar to the point above about sourceElementId, with one exception: if the mapping refers to a Sub Process, it's possible to remove the element instance by referring to no target element. See the discussion about All active elements require a mapping (including active Sub Processes) above.

 
Additional limitations
This epic will be limited as it only provides basic functionality and focuses on simpler process definitions. However, these are not requirements and may be changed later.
The number of active leaf element instances (i.e. tasks, events, gateways) stays the same

We may add support in future versions for removing or adding leaf element instances through specific mapping instructions, but we believe that this makes the feature unnecessarily complex. Users can use Process Instance Modification to remove or add element instances to a process instance and can combine it with Process Instance Migration in a multi-step procedure to deal with this. See the discussion on Mapping instructions cannot change the element type for an example of such a procedure changing step 2 to remove or add an element instance.


Concept
A new MigrateProcessInstance RPC will be added to Zeebe's Gateway to allow clients to migrate process instances. This RPC requires specifying a migration plan. This migration plan consists of mapping instructions specifying how active elements in the source process are migrated to elements in the target process.
A simple migration example is migrating an active Service Task A to a process with that same Service Task A and a Service Task B after it. The mapping instructions specify that A is mapped to A. After the migration, the process instance is still waiting at Service Task A, and when completing its Job the process flows to Service Task B.

Reference-level details

We'll introduce a new MigrateProcessInstance RPC. This API allows for defining a migration plan consisting of a target process definition and a set of mapping instructions. Each instruction looks like [source element id -> target element id]. The RPC takes a MigrateProcessInstanceRequest similar to the following structure (note that the naming and structure are not yet definitive):
message MigrateProcessInstanceRequest {
  // key of process instance to migrate
  int64 processInstanceKey = 1;

  MigrationPlan migrationPlan = 2;

  message MigrationPlan {
    // the process definition key to migrate to
    int64 targetProcessDefinitionKey = 1;
    // source (to migrate from) element id and target element id (to migrate to)
    repeated MappingInstruction mappingInstructions = 2;
  }

  message MappingInstruction {
    // the element id to migrate from
    string sourceElementId = 1;
    // the element id to migrate to
    string targetElementId = 2;
  }
}
When migrating an instance, we adjust the active element instances in Zeebe's state using ProcessInstance:ELEMENT_MIGRATED events. These make sure that the following information is updated:

processDefinitionKey: the key of the target process definition
bpmnProcessId: the BPMN ID of the target process definition
version: the version of the target process definition
elementId: changes to the mapped element ID (note that the mapping may define the sourceElementId and the targetElementId as equivalent, in which case it stays the same)
flowScopeKey: may change if the element exists within a different (sub)-process in the target process definition, e.g. when a new sub-process wraps the element or when a wrapping sub-process is removed in the diff between the source and target process definitions)

Similarly, we will adjust other entities:

jobs with Job:MIGRATED
variables with Variable:MIGRATED
incidents with Incident:MIGRATED
(eventually) event subscriptions like Timer:MIGRATED and SignalSubscription:MIGRATED, but these are kept out-of-scope initially by recreating event subscriptions

In the following example, both the element instance of the Process and the element instance of the active Service Task A are adjusted using ProcessInstance:ELEMENT_MIGRATED events. The Job associated with Service Task A is also adjusted using a Job:MIGRATED event. If any Process Variables exist on the process instance, then these are adjusted using Variable:MIGRATED events.

We also need to adjust the internal entities (these exist in the state only and don't have their own associated records):

Event Scope Instance, requires changes to interrupting and boundary element ids
EventTrigger, requires changes to elementId (but likely does not require adjustment for migrated instances)

Such internal entities can either:

be adjusted through the ProcessInstance:ELEMENT_MIGRATED events
be promoted to have their own records so they can be adjusted through *:MIGRATED events

Note that any entities introduced for new features will also need MIGRATED events to be adjusted. For example:

#14938
#14920
#11217

Changing the element hierarchy
Migrated activities do not have to remain descendants of their closest migrating ancestor scope (Hierarchy Preservation) like in Camunda 7. Instead, a Sub Process can be added in the target process, nesting an element active in the source process. Zeebe will assume that the user intends to create a new element instance of the Sub Process that can be used as the ancestor scope of the active element.
In the following example, we see that element instance B is mapped to an element B that is nested inside A New Sub Process. A new element instance (with a new key) will be created for the element A New Sub Process using ProcessInstance:ELEMENT_ACTIVATING and ProcessInstance:ELEMENT_ACTIVATED. The flow scope (i.e. ancestor scope) of the element instance B is then adjusted to the key of the newly created instance of A New Sub Process using ProcessInstance:ELEMENT_MIGRATED.
This is recursive behavior, meaning that multiple nesting Sub Processes can be added simultaneously.

Likewise, a Sub Process in the source process may be removed in the target process. Zeebe will assume that the ancestor scope of the removed Sub Process instance can be used as the ancestor scope of any element active in that Sub Process.
This is recursive behavior, meaning that multiple nesting Sub Processes can be removed simultaneously.

Other Teams


 Operate
 Tasklist
 Web Modeler
 Desktop Modeler
 Optimize

Discussions and Decisions

How to copy local variables of sub-processes when the scope hierarchy changes?
In Camunda7, there is a requirement for hierarchy preservation. It may be, that we don't have this same requirement in Zeebe. However, this lack presents ambiguity when it comes to copying variables of sub-processes.
A potential solution would be introducing Variable Mapping Instructions to the Migration Plan, where the user can specify exactly where to move variables when removing a Sub Process from the hierarchy.
This functionality can be kept out of scope for now.
How should we deal with process instances in non-wait states?
When the engine completes an element and flows to the next element, it:

marks the element as completed
marks the outgoing sequence flow as taken
and appends a command to activate the next element for the process instance

This means that there are moments in time when an element is not active in the state. Rather the sequence flow is taken, and a not-yet-processed command describes the continuation of the process execution.
After migrating the instance, such unprocessed commands will still be attempted to be processed, but they will be rejected because they refer to the now terminated source process instance.
This scenario also exists for Process Instance Modification, as the referenced process instance key stays the same for both modification and migration. However, parts of the process instance could be terminated, for which unprocessed commands could also be rejected.
For Process Instance Migration, other information (e.g. process definition key) has changed since the command was appended. What we could do to resolve this, is to never trust this data in ProcessInstance commands and always look up the current process definition by doing a lookup of the element instance by key. By trusting the state over the data in commands, we may be able to process more commands correctly.
Still, an element activation command may be unprocessed targeting a no longer existing element id. In that case, the command will simply be rejected. The user may need to use Process Instance Modification to rectify the process instance state.
This scenario might not be too problematic, as it only affects non-wait states. Migration is typically done from wait state to wait state (e.g. user task to user task, service task to service task, etc), where the process has already reached that specific point and is awaiting further instructions from the client. For the cases where this affects non-wait states, modification can be used by the user to rectify any tokens lost during migration. In the future, process instance suspension may be used to stop process execution and increase the user's control over the process migration.

Product Hub (internal): camunda/product-hub#1829

title: [EPIC] Add support for BPMN compensation events
bodyText:
Introduction
We execute tasks in our processes that sometimes have to be canceled later under certain circumstances. BPMN compensation events and compensation handlers are a very powerful construct for handling such situations.
Without these BPMN symbols, users would have to add a lot of additional complexity to their models.

Concept

BPMN compensation events are part of the BPMN 2.0 standard (chapter 13.4.5 Compensation, page 441).
In this iteration, we plan to implement the following features of compensation events:

Add support for compensation events:

Compensation boundary events
Compensation intermediate throw events
Compensation end events
Compensation start events (i.e. compensation event subprocesses)


Mark activities for compensation (i.e. compensation handlers):

Service Tasks
User Tasks
Send Tasks
Script Tasks
Manual Tasks
Undefined Tasks


Trigger compensation recursively for subprocesses
Access local variables (i.e. snapshot data) from completed subprocesses
Trigger compensation for a given activity (i.e. instead of implicitly for the current scope)

Compensation subscriptions
In order to compensate an activity, we need to keep track of completed activities with a compensation handler. Currently, we remove all data of an element instance from the state when it is completed. So, we need to store the data separately.
The only place to modify the state is within an event applier. An event applier is invoked on writing or replaying an event.
We could extend the existing event applier for the process_instance.COMPLETED event and store the data of the completed activity. But this would introduce additional non-trivial logic to the event applier and would violate our goal to keep the event appliers simple (i.e. only apply/write the state changes of the event).
A better way is to move the logic in the processors and introduce a new record to manage the subscriptions for compensation.
Compensation subscription
========================

Record:
- tenant id
- process instance key
- process definition key
- element id of activity with compensation handler
- flow scope element id of activity with compensation handler
- element id of compensation throw event
- element instance key of compensation throw event
- local variables of activity with compensation handler (i.e. snapshot data)

-----------------------------------------

Lifecyle:
CREATED -> TRIGGERED -> COMPLETED | DELETED

- on CREATED: 
 - when an activity with a compensation boundary event is completed, or
 - when an embedded subprocess with a compensation event subprocess is completed
 - then add the subscription to the state 
- on TRIGGERED: 
 - when the compensation throw event is activated
 - then set the element instance key and element id of the compensation throw event
 - and update the subscription in the state
- on COMPLETED: 
 - when the compensation handler is completed
 - then remove the subscription from the state
- on DELETED: 
 - when the process instance is completed or terminated
 - then remove the subscription from the state 

-----------------------------------------

State:
< process instance key | subscription key > -> subscription record

- the subscription key can be used for the reverse ordering


Task Breakdown

Broker

 #14942
 #14943
 #14944
 #14965
 #14967
 #15063
 #14970
 #15066
 #15065
 #15064
 #15068

 #15152

 #15333

Gateway API

No changes in the gRPC API.
Exporters and Metrics


 #15140
 camunda/zeebe-analytics#23

Testing


 #15495
 #15496
 #15498

Zeebe Process Test


 camunda/zeebe-process-test#995

Documentation


 camunda/camunda-docs#2802

Out of scope

Mark activities for compensation (i.e. compensation handlers):

Call activites
Embedded subprocesses


Trigger compensation recursively for child process instances
Support compensation event subprocess on process level
Don’t wait until compensation is completed
Invoke compensation handlers synchronously in reverse order
Optionally invoke compensation handlers if the activities are activated but not completed yet
Support for BPMN cancel events
Support for BPMN transactional subprocess

Other Teams


 Operate
 Tasklist
 Web Modeler
 Desktop Modeler
 Optimize

Discussions and Decisions

Invoke compensation handlers in reverse order
According to the BPMN specification, the compensation handlers are invoked in the reserve order of the execution.

(BPMN 2.0, 13.4.5 Compensation, page 442)
We don't plan to follow this rule. Instead, we will activate the compensation handlers altogether.
Consider the following example:

Assuming that the tasks "A" and "B" are completed. When the compensation end event is reached, we will activate the compensation tasks "Undo A" and "Undo B". Jobs workers can process these jobs concurrently and in any order.
According to the BPMN specification, we should activate the task "Undo B" first. When the task is completed, we should activate the task "Undo A".
In Camunda 7, the reverse order of the compensation is only guaranteed if the compensation handlers are invoked synchronously (i.e. via JavaDelegate). Asynchronous or external tasks are activated concurrently.
Since Camunda 8 works mainly with external tasks, the behavior will be the same.
If the order of the compensation handlers is important, the user could trigger the compensation for the activities explicitly. See the following example.

Interrupt compensation handlers
Can a compensation hander be interrupted/canceled?
Consider the following examples:

The compensation handler is in the same scope as an interrupting event subprocess.



The compensation handler is inside an embedded subprocess that has an interrupting boundary event.



The compensation handler is in the same scope as a termination end event.


In Camunda 7, a compensation handler can be interrupted. In some of these cases, the process instance might end in an invalid state where the instance is stuck in the compensation throw event.
The BPMN specification is not clear about this scenario. It mentions only the following:

[A compensation activity] is outside the normal flow of the Process.

This statement could indicate that compensation handlers are not affected by interrupting events.
❓ How should we handle it in Camunda 8?
Invoke compensation handler for an activity with an incident
When triggering compensation, we invoke the compensation handlers of all completed activities. But what about activities with an incident in a COMPLETING state?
In this case, the underlying job of the activity has been completed but the variable output mapping failed to apply. From a BPMN perspective, the activity itself is not completed. However, the action and possible side effects were executed.
To undo the action, it could make sense to invoke the compensation handler even if the activity is not completed.
In Camunda 7, we don't have this case because there is no COMPLETING state. If the output mapping (or execution listener) fail then the transaction is rolled back and the activity is still active.
❓ How should we handle it in Camunda 8?
Links


Product Hub (internal): camunda/product-hub#219
Public roadmap issue: camunda/issues#56
Camunda 7 documentation: https://docs.camunda.org/manual/7.19/reference/bpmn20/events/cancel-and-compensation-events/

Discussions and Decisions

Invoke compensation handlers in reverse order
According to the BPMN specification, the compensation handlers are invoked in the reserve order of the execution.

(BPMN 2.0, 13.4.5 Compensation, page 442)
We don't plan to follow this rule. Instead, we will activate the compensation handlers altogether.
Consider the following example:

Assuming that the tasks "A" and "B" are completed. When the compensation end event is reached, we will activate the compensation tasks "Undo A" and "Undo B". Jobs workers can process these jobs concurrently and in any order.
According to the BPMN specification, we should activate the task "Undo B" first. When the task is completed, we should activate the task "Undo A".
In Camunda 7, the reverse order of the compensation is only guaranteed if the compensation handlers are invoked synchronously (i.e. via JavaDelegate). Asynchronous or external tasks are activated concurrently.
Since Camunda 8 works mainly with external tasks, the behavior will be the same.
If the order of the compensation handlers is important, the user could trigger the compensation for the activities explicitly. See the following example.

Interrupt compensation handlers
Can a compensation hander be interrupted/canceled?
Consider the following examples:

The compensation handler is in the same scope as an interrupting event subprocess.



The compensation handler is inside an embedded subprocess that has an interrupting boundary event.



The compensation handler is in the same scope as a termination end event.


In Camunda 7, a compensation handler can be interrupted. In some of these cases, the process instance might end in an invalid state where the instance is stuck in the compensation throw event.
The BPMN specification is not clear about this scenario. It mentions only the following:

[A compensation activity] is outside the normal flow of the Process.

This statement could indicate that compensation handlers are not affected by interrupting events.
❓ How should we handle it in Camunda 8?
Invoke compensation handler for an activity with an incident
When triggering compensation, we invoke the compensation handlers of all completed activities. But what about activities with an incident in a COMPLETING state?
In this case, the underlying job of the activity has been completed but the variable output mapping failed to apply. From a BPMN perspective, the activity itself is not completed. However, the action and possible side effects were executed.
To undo the action, it could make sense to invoke the compensation handler even if the activity is not completed.
In Camunda 7, we don't have this case because there is no COMPLETING state. If the output mapping (or execution listener) fail then the transaction is rolled back and the activity is still active.
❓ How should we handle it in Camunda 8?
